text: okay it's 20 past so i think we can start so first of all i want to say a massive welcome to everyone
uh who's attending ndc oslo so this this is my fourth time speaking at ndc oslo so it's
a shame that i can't be be there in person today but you know we are where we are in the world at the moment
it's a great privilege to be here again speaking at this wonderful conference so this talk is called fighting back
against a distracted world where we're going to talk about distraction now when i originally drafted this talk it was back in december last year
and the world was a completely different place back then so i first presented this talk in uh ndc
london uh back in january say the world is very different so you know we'll try and take some of
that into account but obviously hopefully everyone's going to start going back to normal fairly soon i know
countries in europe are at various different stages of easing their lockdowns as you know as are we in the uk but i think
we're a bit behind the rest of europe this is all going to be about you know how we deal with
distraction and sort of be productive so i want to start off with a quote here so this is
from a book a table two cities written by charles dickens and it starts off by saying it was the best of times
it was the worst of times it was the age of wisdom and it was the age of foolishness
and these opening sentence while this opening sentence is just as relevant now as it was back then
when this book was written so we do live in the best of times from a technology standpoint we have
unbelievable technology i mean i'm sitting here in rural derbyshire in the center of england talking to a global
audience at a conference using a webcam and a microphone which is pretty amazing it's also the worst of times because
even though we have all this amazing technology you know we have social media so we've permanently connected with
everyone around the world we have netflix amazon prime disney plus which is amazing you know
constantly streaming this information and you know content that we can watch it's the worst of times because there's
so many things vying for our attention which can make it really hard
to be productive so why do we you know why do we care
about this so what i want to do is i want to talk a bit about my own sort of personal journey and some of the things i've had to overcome
um to do with sort of distraction and being productive this is a lot about personal experience
which i hope you can translate into your own lives as well um but this very much is not a i hate
technology talk that's not the purpose of this talk at all technology is fantastic and but i want to talk about how we can be less
distracted by it so we can actually achieve more in our lives so a little bit of context so back in
2017 in july i made the decision to quit my full-time job and
sort of go solo working for myself so for me this meant i was creating pluralsight courses full time
because that's what i predominantly do is income now i do courses for pluralsight
so one day i went into i went into work i handed my resignation into my boss and i worked my one month's notice
and at the end of july i was free i was working for myself that's quite funny
because at the time i had just recently turned 40 and whilst i've been planning
making this move uh to leave my job for quite a while you know i mean i was obviously saying me and my wife have
been discussing for quite a while a lot of my friends actually sort of got in touch with me and asked me if i was okay because i just turned 40 and i quit
my job so they were wondering if i was having a mid-life crisis which was uh quite funny but i wasn't having a
mid-life crisis i just had things i wanted to do with my life that didn't involve working for someone
else because you know like everyone else you know i had i had a boss
who you know wanted me to do work for them and i was very lucky and that the last job i was in actually got on really well with my boss
and the leaders of the company but you know i've worked for companies before just like everyone else where you might have a leader or a manager who
maybe isn't quite as good as what you'd hope and you know i was kind of getting a bit sick of that so i wanted to be my own
boss so at this point you know i quit my job i set up my
office at home and i was living the high life i was doing my own thing working for myself and it was fantastic after about nine
months i found myself you know i was working in my house i had my office set up in the dining room i've got a nice view of the
garden to the right and some doors to my left which lead into the lounge so lots of nice natural light it was
great working environment after a while i'd find i'll just take the laptop and then go and sit in the lounge on the
sofa and yeah just put sync on tv just like in the background um you know maybe put the news on or
just start watching something on netflix and before i realized it i'd actually binge watched 10 seasons of big bang
theory i was working at the same time i wasn't just watching big bang theory i was doing stuff with this on in the
background i got to the end of the ten seasons and i was like what the hell am i doing i've just sat here and watched
over the space of a few months ten seasons of something which i thought was a bit crazy and part of the problem was
is i started to have cabin fever set in i was in the house constantly all the time now obviously as i said
when i wrote this talk it was before we was in this current sort of lockdown situation so you know obviously all of us have been
forced to be in our houses constantly which does result in cabin fever quite a lot of the time
but before we had these strange times you know i was starting to get a bit of cabin fever at home where i was actually resenting being in the house
because i was living there i've got a wife i've got two children so as well as living my life with my
family i was also working and after a while you start to find it difficult to separate those boundaries between work
and home life well i did certainly some people don't get affected by this so much my wife has
been a homeworker for the last 16 years and she's never had a problem she's never had cabin fever but for me
i was finding it a real problem so at that point i thought you know now's the time to actually get out of the house so i rented a desk in a
co-working space this is my desk probably the tightest it had ever been on day one of working in a co-working
space this was fantastic so i'm still working for myself but there was other like-minded people in the same room who
were running their own businesses so it kind of gave me some of that office vibe back you know we had lots of
office banter which was fantastic you know i kind of missed the office chit chat but there was none of the
competing for jobs and stuff like that because everyone in the co-working space was doing their own thing
you know they're all freelancers so no one was competing with each other but we kind of had this office office banter and after a while an
opportunity for my own office came up in the same in the same building which is here this
is where i'm sitting now so the black chair there on the left that is indeed why i'm sitting at the moment
this is great because it meant i had a place that i could go and do my work you know when i'm in this office i am doing work
when i'm at home i am at home and presents for my wife and children and this led me to do quite a bit of
self-reflection on kind of what is the nature of work and our working environments and what it
means you know to be productive and to try and minimize distractions which is kind of culminated on me
putting this talk together so some of the things i want to talk about are procrastination and
distraction i want to talk a bit about social media addiction because at one point i was
heavily addicted to social media facebook was my particular poison in this case i just spent far too much time
on it i want to talk a bit about self motivation and kind of what motivation
means and then we're going to round out with some general productivity and time management tips just small little things
that maybe you're doing already or maybe you're not and could actually sort of help you in your day-to-day work as i said before
this isn't uh i hate technology talk it's not what this talks about at all so
i love technology i've been a professional software developer for over 25 years now and i love sitting in
front of this big slab of glass in front of me yeah it nothing brings me more joy than doing that
but these amazing machines are also vying for our attention which can be a big problem now i also
don't want to come across as preaching to you or telling you what to do so i have no right to tell you what to do and
i'm not going to i'm going to talk about you know my own personal journey my personal story
and hopefully some of it you can take away and apply yourself or some of it may not be relevant you know it completely depends
on the individual watching it watching the talk a lot of this comes from my own kind of personal experience and struggles of
trying to be accountable for my own actions when it comes to being productive for my work so first of all let's
talk about uh distraction and more importantly is evil evil brother procrastination
procrastination um is something that can really all
of us in our work i used to be a chronic procrastinator my wife actually used to joke
that my name was half a job haunts because i'd have all these wonderful ideas that i wanted to do and i would just
never get them completed i mean just like everyone else i've got a github github account that's like a graveyard of abandoned projects
um you know most people are the same as that so what is procrastination so it is the
habit of putting off or delaying especially something requiring immediate attention
so we've all been there uh you know your boss has asked you to produce a report or you've been given a particularly
grotty task out of the scrum backlog it has to be done but it's not particularly exciting you're
not inspired by this task whatsoever so what do you do well you might watch something on youtube or you might
do something which is commonly referred to as procrasti working where you do other tasks which make you look busy but
actually you're just delaying putting off what you're supposed to be doing so i've done this before i used to go off and just refactor code
which didn't really need refactoring but i'd refactor it to make myself look busy and to think that i'm doing something
meaningful and actually i should have just been working on the real task and then you delay that real task until right till the end and
then you get in a panic you start feeling stressed and then you rush out a half-hour's job on that task
so what are the dangers of procrastination well it stops you achieving your goals for a start because
you're constantly putting things off and delaying what you should be doing
it stops you from acting so by having a level of procrastination
where you might fear actually doing the job it actually stops you from doing it and taking those initial steps to completing a task or a piece of work
can be quite hard it stops you from challenging yourself because you naturally over time start
becoming more lazy towards your work because you get into this habit of not doing things until the last minute
so then because you end up rushing um you don't actually end up challenging yourself because you're constantly trying to play catch up with what you're
supposed to be doing and this in turn leads to high stress levels and prolonged levels of stress over a long
period of time it's not good for you it really is bad for you
so why do we procrastinate well one of the biggest reasons is a fear of failure and this is
something that i found as well so when i was a lot younger you know in my 20s maybe early 30s
when a new technology comes out or a new framework you feel kind of energized and really keen to go and
learn um this new thing what i found and i you know i i don't
know the general age group of people in the talk but the older you get when
you have to learn new things you kind of get a bit afraid of it so now like you know microsoft's come out with blazer
and blazer web assembly and all these new fantastic things and they're brilliant but part of me thinks
oh it's another thing to learn and i'm getting a bit slower at this and what if i screw it up and you've got
all these younger people coming in you're going to do a better job and you kind of have this fear of failure
and everyone has a fear of failure to a certain degree and you know it is quite common that fear can sort of get more amplified as
we get older as well well certainly it certainly does for me procrastinators can tend to be
perfectionists um where you have to feel like everything has to be absolutely perfect
or otherwise you're just not happy and you're not satisfied but because you're worried that the work you're doing isn't going to be perfect
you might try and delay and putting off doing it because if it's not going to be perfect why should i bother
it's kind of a general feeling low energy levels as well um you know
i've certainly found this certainly over the last few months you know we tried me and my wife are trying to homeschool two children one of one of my kids has
adhd and autism which makes calling very very difficult
and then while we're doing that we're both still trying to do our day jobs as well you know i have deadlines i have to
achieve my work is still in a full-time salary job so we're trying to you know do everything in shifts and sort of share
the workload of homeschooling and by the end of the day you know i know i've still got stuff to do for some deadlines but you just feel
absolutely exhausted by the time you get to the end of the day and you know that also leads to
procrastination because if you're tired you think oh i can't be bothered i'll just do it tomorrow
and which in turn leads to a lack of focus and because if you're tired if you've got a fear of failure or you just
feel as though you can't do something well enough to satisfy yourself you just lose your focus completely
so procrastination can really be a really really horrible trap that you can fall into and i've been
there i've i've been in jobs before where i've been constantly playing catch up just because
i haven't had the self-discipline to push myself into getting that work done
okay so some techniques for decreasing your chances of procrastination so first of all we need to accept that we're not
perfect and you know and i'm going to talk about perfection as well when we start looking
at social media is that sometimes we might look at other people that we work with or other people on the
internet and so-called you know influencers and famous techie people and you know they're
writing articles and doing videos and speaking on youtube and all that and sometimes you might think to yourself well
i'm not as good as that person what you don't see is that actually behind the scenes they probably put in
a huge amount of work to try and make themselves sound confident when really they're just the same as us you know
they're not perfect and sometimes you just need to accept that you're not perfect you just need to try and do your
best you also need to understand that failure is not fatal you know if you mess
something up you know the world isn't suddenly going to spin off his axis and crash into the sun if you make a mistake on something and
you do something wrong okay fine you know what did you do wrong
can you learn from it because most failures can be turned into a you know learning exercise where you
you know you learn from it and then you do better next time aim to do your best and be happy about
the outputs you know doing this talk here i mean this is very weird you know i can see now looking at the screen i
think i've got 67 people listening i can't see any of you and it kind of feels a bit weird and
whilst i'm an experienced public speaker actually doing this talk in front of a webcam right now he's
probably the most nervous i've been doing the talk but you know we are where we are and i'm just going to be happy with how it turns
out and you know hopefully it's going to be good uh this one you know tried to develop a
healthier lifestyle to get more energy it goes back to the you know you should be eating healthily and
getting more exercising you know everyone goes on about how we should be healthier but it is really true
um i've certainly found during lockdown because i've been forcing
myself to go out and do walks every day i've actually been the fittest i think i've probably ever been well certainly
for the last 15 years but if you're fitter and you're eating well and you're well hydrated it makes
your brain more alert and it makes you better at you know just getting on with some work and instead of being sort of tired and
lethargic and putting that work off another one is going to bed earlier
goes about saying the more sleep you have the more alert you're going to be in the
morning and also reducing screen time before bed i mean this is easier said than done
but having lots of you know light blurring into your eyes before you go to sleep can generally lead to restless
sleep it makes you tired and cranky in the morning and then you think oh i can't be bothered to get this work done or if you
can't reduce using the screen i mean a lot of devices now you know i tend to use an ipad late at night it has
it's like nighttime mode where it kind of takes a lot of the blue hints out of the screen so that it's not as glaring on your eyes
so even using things like that is quite good so procrastination is a big problem
you think that people need to recognize and you know try and make a concerted effort to to not put things off try and get work
done and started as soon as you physically can okay so now i want to talk about uh
controlling social media addiction now as i mentioned before i was massively addicted to facebook i'm
going to talk about kind of different networks in a moment and social media
addiction is an addiction like anything else i mean alcohol can be addictive smoking can be addictive
and drugs as well can be addictive but social media can be just as addictive because you
know you post something you know you're sitting there waiting for the likes and that can make you feel great
and just like where you know you have a glass of wine kind of you know relaxes you a bit it makes you feel feel better
uh strange i mean when you're out commuting you know remember the days when we're allowed to commute
you know you'd sit on a train or a bus and this is kind of the thing that you'd see quite commonly
you know people were just sitting there nobody's really having a conversation or engaging with each other but everyone's sitting there on
instagram uh youtube facebook twitter probably in my
children's case it's tick-tock these days because that's since where all the all the cool people hang
it's kind of a real shame that people losing this kind of real social interaction but then just
pushing all of our social interaction down onto a little screen which is kind of a shame
so the way social media affects us it affects us in different ways with different hormones and neurotransmitters
so i'm going to run through i mean i'm not a biologist by any stretch but i'm going to talk about some of the different neurotransmitters and hormones and the
way these things affect our brains so the first one is dopamine so this is
a neural transmitter or neurotransmitter rather that is used for reward reinforcement and pleasure so
posing on social media and getting likes and having people you know write nice comments
makes you feel good it elevates those dopamine levels in your brain and because it makes you feel good and you get that nice little hit of
happiness you do it again and you do it again and then after a while it becomes addictive so it is
kind of a similar effect to drugs and alcohol you know you someone takes drugs they get that massive dopamine hits or alcohol you
know it makes you feel relaxed and a bit happier especially after you've had um a particularly bad day actually i'm not
condoning the use of drugs or alcohol but the effects they have on you are they give you this hit of dopamine which is
exactly the same as posting on social media some quick fixes
for getting dopamine is to try and look for your rewards from
elsewhere so i find if i'm working on something just completing a task even even a small task or a goal and then
physically ticking it off in my notepad that kind of makes you feel good and when you have larger pieces of work it's
kind of a good idea to break that work down into lots of smaller little tasks and then actually physically write them
down and now i've i've gone through pretty much every single productivity tool on the mac and windows you can ever
think of i've actually gone back to using you know a moleskine notebook and a pen and i write my tasks down and then when
i've done it i put a big physical tick next to it and that kind of makes you feel good exercising and sightseeing you know
exercise is proven to make you feel better it gives you a good dopamine hit so i tend to go out walking quite a lot
i live in rural derbyshire in the center of england so we have lots of hills and lots of nice countryside so i tend to go out a
lot and do lots of walking that makes me feel good when i do that also finishing a book you know if you're
reading a novel or a non-fiction book you know just getting to the end of that book i mean that's an achievement and it makes you feel good
the next one is melatonin so melatonin is a hormone and that governs your circadian rhythm
which is your sleep and wake cycle this is why i'm saying if you use screens late at night or if you're
watching tv or using your laptop or tablet or looking at your phone the glare from
that screen suppresses melatonin production which then messes up your sort of sleeping cycles
so when you sleep you go through a different cycle through the night so you go through you know your sort of lighter rem sleep
where you dream and then you go into your deep sleep which is where your body does a lot of its restoration and sort
of files all of your memories into into long-term storage if you don't have that melatonin
produced at the right times then it can mess up that cycle and then when you wake up in the morning you actually probably feel worse than you
did before you went to bed so good ways of enhancing melatonin and
regulating your circadian rhythms is getting some sunshine so some actual outdoor sunlight
in the uk we don't have a lot of that although the past few weeks have been quite nice but good sunshine outside is is good for
you avoiding screens late at night or if you must use the screen you try and
put your nighttime mode on a warm bar for a shower before bed really helps relax you and just helps
you get to sleep and also reading before bed
ideally on something like a kindle or an actual physical paper book
okay so next one is oxytocin so oxytocin is a transmitter that
affects social interaction sexual chemistry and bonding between family and friends
so oxytocin levels in our bodies increase with physical social interactions so you know
hanging out with your family friends hugging kissing that sort of thing although obviously social distancing a lot of those things are quite hard at
the moment now virtual interactions do increase oxytocin levels but it's only slightly it's nothing like
the real thing um which is like you know one of the reasons i've got into actual you know
like in person conferences is on one hand you've got all the fantastic talks and the content but you're
you're there interacting with people you know you're shaking hands with people or giving your friends a hug and just
having conversations and that's great and that's what helps release oxytocin
into your brain so quick fixes for that is you know making sure that you know if you do spend a lot of time
in front of a computer like we all do you spend more time with family and friends in the real world
actually doing real things as and when we can playing with your children so one thing
i found when i was working from home full time because all of my work equipment was in
easy reach you started getting to the point where you know the kids will come home from school
and you know i'm supposed to be playing with my children that's why we have children we want to play with them but then you think well i've got this
task which i didn't quite finish and then you kind of feel stressed because you haven't got this thing finished and it's right there you should
be playing with your kids and you kind of get into this kind of trap but you know playing with children
having real conversations and physical contact with people is a good way of regulating your oxytocin levels
and finally we have serotonin which is a neurotransmitter which contributes to the feeling of happiness and well-being
so high levels of this boost you move they make you feel happy and energetic low levels of serotonin are linked with
um sort of depression some mental health conditions and general lethargy as well where you
just feel too tired and you just can't be bothered to do something that you know you should be doing
so low levels of serotonin cancer cause negative thoughts in your mind it can make you irritable it can make you
anxious so generally it's not a nice position to be in if your serotonin levels are out
of balance and something i found with social media which can affect your serotonin production is it can really affect your
self-worth and it creates a culture of envy and inadequacy i mean how many times do you know do you
go on to things like instagram where people are posting all the wonderful things in their life whether they're real or whether they're
just fake and posed nobody ever really posts the bad stuff that happens you know the fact that the kids have woken you up at three o'clock
in the morning and you look like a cat that's been dragged through a hedge when you wake up nobody posts that stuff
they just post the really good stuff so if you're just constantly scrolling through your instagram feed and you're just bombarded
with everyone's happy wonderful life yet you know that you're struggling at the moment it can really affect your self-worth and
it's really quite dangerous i think again things that can help
regulate serotonin levels is um exercise and sunshine at the same time is even better
just trying to physically make sure you maintain a positive outlook you know doing affirmations
every day where you sort of physically tell yourself that you know you are doing a good job what you're doing is worthwhile and you
know you should keep on doing the good things that you do you know be positive you know the glass
is half full it's not half empty

facebook so at one point i had 750 so-called

motivation is something that most people experience at some point in their lives and by this i mean
you just sit there in the morning you know you've got some tasks to do but you just really don't feel like it you're not motivated
there's different types of motivation so we've got intrinsic motivation this is where you have an internal desire that motivates you
so you might have goals that you want to pursue and you feel like you want to achieve those goals and you have this inner drive to succeed
but you also have what's called extrinsic motivation and this comes from an external source such as your boss
telling you that you need to be more productive so you may not feel intrinsically motivated
to do a task but you have an external factor kind of chipping away you say no you have to do this you have to do this
piece of freelance work otherwise you won't get paid that's an extrinsic motivation but also when we talk about motivation
there's something called the locative control which is uh something i became aware of last year and it's quite an interesting
uh concept so the locus of control is the capacity to which you believe you
have complete control and power over what happens in your life and you can think of the locus of
controls kind of on the spectrum so you have your external locus of control and your internal
now one person doesn't live at any one point permanently on that spectrum you can
kind of move kind of in between but external locus of control is where you think that your
achievements are outside of your control they're determined by fate and they're independent of your
hard work or decisions so for example you might think yeah i completed this really complex task but
it wasn't just me it's because bob helped me with this and sarah helped me with that and it was them that helped me achieve it
so you're not giving yourself the credit for doing that work you're attributing it to something else it's
your internal locus of control is where you think your achievements are within your control determined by your hard work
or decisions so you might be i completed this work because i worked bloody hard to do it and it was hard i had to research a load
of stuff i had to learn some stuff i had to read some books and read articles but it was all down to me and i think
you know having an internal locus of control where you believe that everything you do is kind of down to
how you behave and how you act is kind of healthy or healthier whereas an external locus
of control is where you're not really giving yourself the credit for the work that you do and we can flip between the two um quite
commonly and another way of thinking about this as well is that
it's about worrying about what you can personally control day-to-day so there's some things you can control there's some things that
